intro: Dysopsis glechomoides var. genuina, commonly known as the Mexican nettle, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Central America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its opposite, ovate leaves with serrated margins. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers arranged in clusters, which are typically borne on slender pedicels. Its leaves are often covered with fine, stinging hairs, similar to those found in nettles. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in forest understories.
